contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "wandering" and "going back and forth" refer to the activity of traveling all over the earth in order to emphasize its completeness. Alternate translation: "From going everywhere on the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: From wandering on the earth, from going back and forth on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two clauses describe the darkness of the day of Job's birth, thus repeating Job's regret that he had been born. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: May that day be dark ... neither may the sun shine on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses two sentences to think about what it would be like if he had never been born or had died at birth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: For now I would have been lying down quietly. I would have slept and been at rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses parallelism to emphasize what he is saying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: who once had gold, who had filled their houses with silver

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job uses parallelism to emphasize that the lowly will find rest from those causing them hardship. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: There the wicked cease from trouble; there the weary are at rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's two questions mean basically the same thing. He is wondering why those who face hardship continue to live. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Why is light given to him who is in misery? Why is life given to the one who is bitter in soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job expresses his anguish in two ways. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For my sighing happens instead of eating; my groaning is poured out like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "what I feared most has happened to me" or "my worst fear has come true" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: the thing that I feared has come on me; what I was afraid of has come to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job expresses his anguish in three separate phrases. Alternate translation: "I am very anxious" or "I am emotionally and physically tormented" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I am not at ease, I am not quiet, and I have no rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This verse states a single idea in two different ways. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: See, you have instructed many; you have strengthened weak hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallelism in each of these verses to make one idea using two different statements to emphasize 1) the support that Job has given others in the past, 2) the effect on him of his present troubles, and 3) his piety before God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer explains a single idea using two different statements. This is a form of Hebrew poetry used for emphasis, clarity, teaching, or all three. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: By the breath of God they perish; by the blast of his anger they are consumed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using different statements to emphasize God's destruction of wicked people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases express the same idea in a different way. They convey the idea that Eliphaz heard a message whispered to him. This repetition is a form of Hebrew poetry used frequently for emphasis, teaching, or clarity. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Now a certain matter was secretly brought to me ... my ear received a whisper about it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using different statements to emphasize Eliphaz's fear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallelism in verse 17, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize a question about the purity of man before God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These verses continue the earlier use of parallelism, here emphasizing in different ways the idea that people die suddenly without having achieved wisdom and without concern from others. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These verses continue the earlier use of parallelism, here emphasizing in different ways the idea that the children of foolish people are never safe. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: In these verses, Eliphaz continues his speech from [Job 4:1](../04/01.md). The writer continues to use parallelism in each verse, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize that Job needs to plead his case to God who does wonderful things. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each verse, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize how God lifts those who are lowly and debases those who are cunning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each verse, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize how God debases those who are cunning and saves those who are poor. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in verses 18 and 19, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize God's acts of chastening and healing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize security with regard to the natural world, the homestead, and one's descendants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer uses two different statements to convey a single idea, the burden of Job's suffering. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "if only I could weigh my anguish and all my calamities in the balance" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: if only my anguish were weighed; if only all my calamity were laid in the balance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize Job's intense suffering as the grounds for his complaint. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job continues to use parallelisms in these verses as he speaks about his sufferings and his desire for death. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallel rhetorical questions in each of these verses to emphasize Job's lack of strength to endure suffering. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed is full of ice and snow in the winter. Alternate translation: "which look dark in the winter because they are covered with ice and are full of melted snow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: which are darkened because of ice over them ... and because of the snow that hides itself in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. They describe how the streambed dries up in the hot season. Alternate translation: "When it is hot, the ice melts and the streambeds dry up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: When they thaw out, they vanish ... when it is hot, they melt out of their place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize that his personal suffering is part of the universal suffering which all people experience. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize Job's sense of the shortness of life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize Job's thought that, after death, neither God nor the people he knew will see him again. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job conveys a single idea using two different statements to emphasize the reason he will not remain silent. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in the first two verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize Job's intense suffering. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to use parallelism in these verses, conveying a single idea using two different statements to emphasize the impact of Job's misery on his sense of self worth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

Here Job conveys a single idea using two different rhetorical questions to emphasize his wish that God would stop watching him. Alternate translation: "Look away from me! Leave me alone long enough for me to swallow my own saliva!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How long will it be ... swallow down my own saliva?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Job uses two similar clauses within a rhetorical question to emphasize his point. Possible meanings are: 1) Job is asking why God does not forgive him. Alternate translation: "Tell me why you do not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity." or 2) Job is asking God why he cannot just overlook his supposed wrongdoings. Alternate translation: "Tell me why you do not just bear with my transgression and iniquity." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you not pardon my transgression and take away my iniquity?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad continues to use parallelism in each of these verses to emphasize that their ancestors agree with the things Bildad is telling Job. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize that the godless person is trusting in something that cannot save him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: His confidence will break apart ... his trust is as weak as a spider's web

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have similar meaning, but the meaning is unclear. Possible meanings are 1) he appears to be well-rooted in the rocks, taking advantage of every opening or 2) his roots cannot find fertile ground and must try to find nutrients among the rocks. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His roots are wrapped about the heaps of stone ... they look for good places among the rocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how happy Job would be if he were innocent. The word "he" refers to God and "your" refers to Job. Alternate translation: "God will make you very happy again if you are innocent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: He will yet fill your mouth with laughter, your lips with shouting

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses parallelism in each of these verses, conveying a single idea using double statements to emphasize that God is great, unseen, and sovereign. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job poses two similar questions to emphasize his reluctance to confront God. They can be reworded as a statement. Alternate translation: "So I certainly could not answer him or choose words to reason with him." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How much less could I answer him, could I choose words to reason with him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This verse expresses the same idea twice for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Though I am in the right, my own mouth would condemn me; and though I am blameless, my words would prove me to be guilty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions have nearly the same meaning. These questions expect a negative answer to emphasize that God does not see or understand things the same way a man does. They can be expressed as statements. Alternate translation: "You do not have eyes of flesh, and you do not see like a man sees." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you have eyes of flesh? Do you see like a man sees?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have nearly the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: your days like the days of mankind ... your years like the years of people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two parallel questions are asking the same thing. The writer uses the form of a question to add emphasis. Alternate translation: "You cannot understand God by searching for him, and you will never completely understand the Almighty!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Can you understand God by searching for him? Can you comprehend the Almighty perfectly?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The impossibility of understanding God is spoken of as if it were impossible to go to these extremely far away places. Alternate translation: "is as inaccessible as the highest places in heaven ... is more inaccessible than the deepest places in Sheol" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: is as high as heaven ... deeper than Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Your life would ... like the morning.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: You would be secure ... take your rest in safety

contextId.occurrenceNote: Zophar repeats the same idea for emphasis and describes the possibility. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: Also you would lie down in rest ... your favor.

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and intensify Job's request for God to listen to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: listen carefully to my speech; let my declaration come to your ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: These three lines express the same thought and are used together to emphasize his confidence that God would forgive him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: My transgression would be ... you would cover up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each verse is a parallelism that contains two rhetorical questions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions are basically the same and are used together to emphasize that a man cannot be perfect. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: What is man ... What is he who is born

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines give a similar image, which is repeated to emphasize that this will surely happen. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will drop his ... he will cast off his

contextId.occurrenceNote: The same thought is repeated three times to emphasize how much evil these people produce. This speaks of a person planning to do evil things and doing them as if the person were conceiving and giving birth to these things as a woman conceives and gives birth to a child. Alternate translation: "They plan to cause mischief and do evil things; they are always planning to deceive others" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They conceive mischief and give birth to iniquity; their womb conceives deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing. Together they emphasize Job's feeling of having been betrayed by God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: hands me over to ungodly people, and throws me into the hands of wicked people

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines are a variation to each other and are used together to emphasize how desperate Job is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I have said to the pit ... and to the worm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Bildad continues to speak and uses three parallel images to describe how suddenly the wicked person will experience disaster. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize the fact that nobody will remember him after he dies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: His memory will perish from the earth; he will have no name in the street

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases together emphasize the fact that the wicked person will be sent to Sheol, the place of the dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will be driven from light into darkness ... and be chased out of this world

contextId.occurrenceNote: Together these two phrases emphasize that he will have no family or descendants left. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will have no son ... nor any remaining kinfolk where he had stayed

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and refer to the same people. Here these people are referred to by the places where they live. Alternate translation: "unrighteous people, those who do not know God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the homes of unrighteous people, the places of those who do not know God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fly away" and "be chased away" represent disappearing. They may also imply being forgotten, since dreams and visions disappear when people forget them. Alternate translation: "He will disappear like a dream ... he will be forgotten like a vision of the night" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He will fly away like a dream ... he will be chased away like a vision of the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: This two clauses mean the same thing and emphasize that this is true. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Their descendants are established with them in their sight ... their offspring are established before their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases mean the same thing because "eyes" refers to sight. Wicked people get to watch their descendants grow strong and wealthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in their sight ... before their eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean that the person is very healthy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: His body is full of milk ... the marrow of his bones is moist

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both questions mean basically the same thing. Eliphaz uses questions to emphasize that a person's actions and wisdom do not benefit God. Alternate translation: "A man cannot be useful to God. A wise man cannot be useful to him." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Can a man be useful to God? Can a wise man be useful to him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Eliphaz uses questions to emphasize that Job's actions do not help God. Alternate translation: "The Almighty does not receive any pleasure if you are righteous. He does not gain anything if you make your ways blameless." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty if you are righteous? Is it gain to him if you make your ways blameless?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eliphaz is accusing Job of taking land from poor people and not allowing them to live on it. He is emphasizing this point by restating it twice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: possessed the earth ... lived in it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to meet with God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Oh, that I knew where ... Oh, that I might come

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to explain his situation to God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: lay my case ... fill my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize Job's desire to hear God's answer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: I would learn the words ... would understand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Each of these verses has the form of a parallelism to emphasize the main point Job makes there. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Job is very afraid of God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For God has made my heart weak; the Almighty has terrified me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines describe the same thing and are used together to emphasize that these people are so hungry that they are forced to steal food at night. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Poor people reap in the night ... they glean grapes

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines describe the same thing and are used together to emphasize that these people do not have enough clothing to keep warm. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: They lie naked ... they have no covering

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions are used together to emphasize that it is impossible for a man to be good enough before God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How then can man ... God? How can he who is born ... him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines say the same thing and are used together to emphasize that man is not perfect. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: How much less man ... a son of man, who is a worm

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have basically the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that he will not speak in such ways. The phrases "My lips" and "my tongue" represent Job himself. Alternate translation: "I will not speak wickedness or deceit" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: My lips will not speak wickedness, neither will my tongue speak deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The two clauses that start with these words share the same meaning. They are used together to emphasize Job's strong desire that this should happen. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Let my enemy be ... let him who rises up against me be

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning. Alternate translation: "when God cuts him off and takes away his life" or "when God causes him to die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: when God cuts him off, when God takes away his life

contextId.occurrenceNote: These clauses express a similar meaning. Alternate translation: "No bird of prey or falcon knows or has ever seen the path that goes to the mine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: No bird of prey knows the path to it ... nor has the falcon's eye seen it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These clauses also express similar meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The proud animals have not walked such a path ... nor has the fierce lion passed there

contextId.occurrenceNote: These questions mean the same thing and are used to show that it is very difficult to find wisdom and understanding. Alternate translation: "It is very difficult to find wisdom and understanding." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Where will wisdom be found? Where is the place of understanding?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This line means the same as the previous line. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: if I have said to fine gold, 'You are what I am confident in'

contextId.occurrenceNote: This would be the reason for hiding his sins. These mean the same thing. They emphasize that a person may hide his sin because he fears what other people may think about him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: because I feared the great multitude, because the contempt of families terrified me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that a man's wisdom comes from God. Alternate translation: "there is a spirit in a man, that is, the breath of the Almighty that" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: there is a spirit in a man; the breath of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that Job must listen carefully. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: hear my speech; listen to all my words

contextId.occurrenceNote: These mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that he is now ready to speak. His "tongue" speaking represents himself speaking. Alternate translation: "I have opened my mouth and I have begun to speak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I have opened my mouth ... my tongue has spoken in my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines mean the same thing. Elihu is emphasizing that God has made him and so gives authority to what he is saying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The Spirit of God ... has given me life

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases have the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a dream ... a vision of the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these statements mean the same thing. Alternate translation: "God saves people from the grave and from death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: God keeps man's life back from the pit ... his life from crossing over to death

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing, that the person is in so much pain that he cannot even eat. The person is represented by his "life" and his "soul." Alternate translation: "the result is that he does not desire any food, not even very special food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: so that his life abhors food, and his soul abhors delicacies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu continues speaking. Each of these verses contain parallel phrases. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have the same meaning and are used together to emphasize that God would never do anything wrong. The phrase "far be it from" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "Almighty God would never consider doing anything that is wicked or wrong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: far be it from God ... far be it from the Almighty that he should commit sin

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these rhetorical questions have the same meaning and emphasize that no one needed to grant God authority because it was already his. These questions can be written as statements. Alternate translation: "No one needed to give permission to God to take responsibility over all the earth. He is the rightful one to rule the world." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who put him in charge over the earth? Who put the whole world under him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: "listen to what I say." This means the same as the previous part of the sentence. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: listen to the sound of my words

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two lines share similar meanings. The second line intensifies the meaning of the first line. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: If you have sinned ... what do you do to him?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his fear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: my heart trembles ... it is moved out of its place

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases have nearly the same meaning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: on lands where no person exists, and on the wilderness, in which there is no one

contextId.occurrenceNote: God expresses the same idea in two different ways in order to emphasize the terrifying appearance of Leviathan. You can make this clear by adding the omitted words. Alternate translation: "Out of his mouth go burning torches, sparks of fire leap out of his mouth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Out of his mouth go burning torches, sparks of fire leap out
